title: Can we be what we really want to be? - Quora

response.answer_text: Nooooo. What is wrong with people nowadays?! You can definitely try, but so will many others. Do you really think that most children who try to play football will become Lionel Messi?! I was born with two left feet. If I were to spend all awake time practicing football I would still not even be worthy of a slot in an EFL Championship team. I mean, I enjoyed playing football and wasn’t horrible at it, but it was mainly because of having strong legs, being tall, being fairly agile while running, having very good explosion/acceleration and so on. But when it comes to actually attempting a long pass … it’s sheer luck if it meets the destination. It might reach the guy, it might not … I don’t know, I don’t ponder, I’m just kicking it and hoping for the best. Point being, you need to be realistic and to know your talents and your shortcomings. Trying to do something you don’t have a good foundation for is just a waste of time. Not to mention we also need to evaluate what others want to be. If we all want to be actors … who will pay us to see the movies?! The world needs plumbers, roofers, carpenters, software engineers, medics, architects and so on. We need to split work and specialise to conquer it. As technology and software engineering evolves, more and more work can be covered by machines and automated, which leaves people in need to respecialise to expand their skillset. You need to look at society realistically, through the eyes of what we want to achieve and how we split and coordinate the efforts to achieve it. This cliche of “You can be anything you want to be” needs to stop. Sure, you should try it, you should have a very disciplined and passionate go at it. But you shouldn’t invest time in some pipe dream. It’s much more important to understand the FUNDAMENTALS of life, society, economy and human/social evolution. That way you will understand that all these dreams that are being nicely packed and sold to you are just a means for some rich bastards to make even more money off you spending time in wishful thinking and buying their dreams. Have a thirst to understand, nurture your curiosity … do what you love. But don’t think you necessarily can be anything you want to be. You can definitely get pretty far with a disciplined and passionate approach, but so will others

Try, and test for yourself if it is true. Reflect on your experiences as you are trying, and listen to it, and see what they tell you. You will often come across such “motivation” and “inspiration”. Not all are true. So how do you know? You can look at others’ experiences, apart from acquiring your own, as sometimes it is too costly, or impractical to test everything you hear yourself. So in this instance, you can google what people say about trying to be anything. Do they succeed or not, and what are the reasons, etc. Then, of course, I am sure you know you have limitations, be it physical, intellectual or financial, or personality, etc. There are some who think these are not limitations, and to be anything including being someone who you are not also. What do you think for yourself? Finally apart from abilities, the other consideration is wisdom. Sure even if you can be anything, how do you choose or select one over another? You just do not have the resources, time and effort, etc, to keep trying be anything. You probably need to focus also in order to be the thing you want to be. But where and what do you focus? How do you get the knowledge and wisdom to know which has the greatest chance of success? Or again all these don’t matter? Whatever you put your heart, mind and muscle to it, you will achieve it? Again this is something you have to think about for yourself.

If you mean that literally, of course not. You can't just decide that you will be a horse. If you are white you can't make yourself black or vice versa. If you're a man you can't turn yourself into a woman or vice versa. Etc, etc. More realistically, if you mean, Can I achieve any goal in life that I want?, the answer is that there are many things that you can achieve, but some are more realistic than others. If you want to be a very good basketball player, you can probably achieve that by training and practice. But if you want to be the star player of a professional team ... no one can promise that you can achieve that. If you were born with all the right attributes AND you work harder than anyone else, maybe so. Theoretically, any American can grow up to be president. But realistically, if you're not a good public speaker, good at making friends, good at making deals, and rich, your chances of becoming president are just about zero. Not to be a downer. I certainly wouldn't discourage anyone from pursuing realistic goals. But what's realistic depends on how hard you are willing to work and what resources you have available. I think a classic challenge in life is choosing the right goals. If you set goals that are too low, than even if you achieve them, so what? I recall a friend of a friend saying that her goal was to become the manager of a McDonalds. Not just any employee, mind you, but the MANAGER. On the other hand if you set goals that are too difficult, you could spend years of your life chasing a hopeless dream. The trick is to set goals that are high enough to be worth pursuing but low enough to be possible. That said, there's an old saying, "Whether you think you can, or you think you can't, you're probably right."

Sadly, No. In an unrealistic way, you cannot become anything. You cannot become a dog is you want to, or a unicorn. You cannot become a wizard or a witch no matter how many times you wave your wand. These are things that are unattainable through the wall we call reality. At the same time, our society will dictate where we go in life. As you grow up, you will constantly be told what you should do, where you should go to college. While you believe the decision is fully yours, it is usually the manifestation of a dream someone else has for you. You're place in society is determined by your grades and behavior. Bad grades and bad attitude? I guess you'll just drop out of school and become a bum. We are told by our limitations and our limiters what we can do. It is unfair, but that is life. However… There is always light in the darkness. Sure, we are told again and again that we cannot do that but we can do this, but just because that is what we are told, doesn't mean that is what we do. If you really, truly, want to do something, I believe that you can achieve it. Your achievement may not be what you were expecting, but whatever it is you were meant to do, you will do it. I believe in fate, but not entirely. I believe that there are things you are fated to do. There are people you are fated to meet. However, I also believe that your journey is not fated. The path you take is entirely your decision. While you will end up wherever you are meant to be, how you got there is completely up to you. To answer your question, Can you truly be whatever you want to be? I think so… Yes.

If you want to become a 9’ tall lizard man, or a fire engine, then no, probably not… but if you mean “ can you become an elite athlete, Navy S.E.A.L., president of the U.S. or great martial artist like Bruce Lee… also probably not, unless you have good genetics and rock solid determination and work ethic. If you mean, can you become an engineer, CEO of a large company, Astronaut, or famous movie star… well maybe, if you REALLY work your ass off, meet the right people (luck), and never give up. Sadly, the true answer is “not really… it depends.” I once read a quote that I think applies to your request…I think it was from a fortune cookie… it said “If your desires are not extravagant they will be granted.” That said, I think you should have extravagant desires… because every now and again someone becomes Tony Robbins, or Taylor Swift, or Dwayne Johnson through hard work and determination and refusing to quit. Could be you next? Probably won’t be… but it could be?

The answer is simply no. I believe this is a dangerous paradigm especially prevalent in the West in the last several decades of parenting. Not only does it ignore questions such as what should we strive to be, it also tends to destroy a sense of direction, which I feel is one of the most important psychological tasks for any parent in helping their children to develop. That’s not to say a parent should dictate, but I do believe it is the job of a good parent to be close enough to - and observant enough of - their child as they develop to insert their wisdom/common sense to help guide that child in making smart choices about their future. Wanting your child to feel good is one thing, but when encouragement comes at the expense of reality, it can actually hurt children in the long run. All you need to do is take a look around at the societal problems we have today, and then look to the millions of children who started growing up 20 years ago in “everyone gets gold stars” and “everyone wins” classrooms.

I believe we can if we don´t need others to validate or acknowledge our choice. I mean, being something is acting as if you were that thing already. Just start being whomever it is you want to be and all of a sudden, you are! If you want to be a gardener, start gardening, if you want to be a writer, start writing. Now, if you need a certificate of some kind, then it may not be an overnight change but you can always move in that direction so someday you´ll eventually become what you have chosen to be, like a doctor or an astronaut. The key here is to believe because life happens at least 70% inside of us first. Everything that is real once only existed inside somebody´s mind. So if there´s a WANT inside you, that´s probably you already are. We must be careful though, if you´re not very connected with yourself you may misinterpret you WANT, like, there are people that want to become millionaires but when they finally do, they´re miserable. I believe that happens because they misinterpret what they wanted, they didn´t really want to accumulate lots and lots of pieces of paper. They were probably after respect, appreciation, maybe even freedom. Also, being what you want may not mean that you´ll become a billionaire just because you´re doing it, but I promise you´ll be rich nonetheless.

Why do you want it?  Do you have a genuine answer of it. If, Yes then make it point. Remember it, remember your goals. Don't let forget own self your goals. Step 1>  Set your goal and type of goal. It is long term or short term what kind of goal this is. Why did you choose this ask to your self about it. Why do you want it? Be sure completely before taking next step, if you need some time then give some time to your self. And then be sure, this is your final goal. Step 2>  Prepare a list of challenges which you will face when you will work for chasing your goals. Think about both aspect positive possibilities and negative possibilities of your goal and prepare upcoming challenges list. This list will help you to be confident for challenging phase. Step 3 >  Remember your goal and more than a goal, remember today's task which are mandatory, make a priority list of today's tasks these tasks should be finished within set time limit. If, you don't remember your daily goals, then you will not able to give priority to mandatory tasks because daily task will help you to reach on next level day by day. Step 4 >  There must be a requirement of many skills to chase your goal. So, analyze your goal and prepare that skill set which is mandatory. Because to do anything in life we need many skills, so become better in some necessary skills on priority like, below skills. How to set goals Analysis skills Management skills Required soft skills Required hard skills Problem solving skills Creative thinking Stress handling skills People skills These are just an example of skill set. So, prepare your own skill set as per your goals. And make a tracker which can help you to track your progress easily on regular basis. And you can get your own feedback of weakness and strength. Note: You can find similar lines easily on internet but, reading things and implementing them both are different things. So, try to be consistent. I hope it must help you!

With the emphasis on “Be”, yes you can. However, if there was emphasis on Anything, then no, not exactly. In my planned education reform, it focuses on “Do that which you can do” while not taking away the hopes & dreams of being what the person wants to be. Some people aspire to be athletes when they are actually good at being musicians & other artists. And some aspiring to be lawyers are actually better off being scientists in the lab. But it also could be due to how their parents raised their kids as well as what the parents have genetically passed onto their kids. So which is better? Both. IF you have what it takes to be in the Navy and/or Coast Guard, but you wanted to be a Veteranarian, you could work with their Dolphins, Seals, & more. So by doing that which you can do while perusing your dreams is the best thing you can do.

My dear correspondent, you ARE exactly what you really want to be. When you want to be something different, you are. I know that I have failed to answer your intended question, but please consider my answer first. I think your intended question is, “Can we, sometime in the future, really become what we want, dream, and plan to be?” The answer to this question is, yes, it is possible — but there are so many variables that one cannot know. When I was 15, I wanted to be a football player, but when I was lifting weights to get strong enough, I blew up a disk or two in my back. So much for football. Injuring myself was not part of my plan. I wanted to be an artist, but I cannot make my fingers draw the shape I see in my mind. I wanted to be a musician, but I have no sense of rhythm. Eventually, I quit trying to be mythic things, and I concentrated on doing what I liked at the moment — and that led me in some amazing directions, about which I had never thought. Life for me is less a plan and more of an adventure. Each to their own taste.

Yes you canheres a list of things you can do starting today to be who you want to be1.step out of your comfort zone2.read all you can the top ceos of today read books all they can3.discover your purpose 4.start practicing enthusiasm5.learn to be a leader read or listen to the 21 irrefutable laws of leadership by john c Maxwell6.Develop yourself work on your weaknesses and develop your strengths7.be proactive-meaning that you take responsibility for your actions you don't complain you are happy about it you want to do it you choose to do it you will do it.8.Think big if you have trouble thinking big read or listen to the magic of Thinking big by david j Schwartz they have a copy of the book on sell on amazon for $9.03.9.Take up different hobbies drawing painting sculpting10.Learn a new skill a language how to invest in stocks11.Act don't just think Act12.I can sum it up in one Quote from Jim Rohn "Everyday stand at the door of your mind" do all this and you can be who you want to be I hope this helps

Can you be whoever you want to be? No. You become your best or worst self, but you will remain human! I once worked at a coffee shop near CAL BERKELEY! Few days went by when staff members had run to prevent patrons, who were probably high on LSD, from trying to fly off the second floor balcony! If they did, they would injure or kill themselves! So in that sense you cannot do whatever you want! However, if you DESIRE some particular field of enterprise, and if you are willing to work for it, it’s surprising what we’re capable of! However, there are still certain limitations. If someone can’t carry a tune, they don’t go into opera. If someone suffers from any form of mental retardation, they shouldn’t do games based on quick mental abilities, and the like!

I believe God has a plan for me from the beginning of time. Of course, it can be altered along the way since sometimes I feel like there's some life events that happened probably for a good reason which I never saw coming. Now I treat it as a good thing- a continous learning process (surely, God is preparing me for something that lies ahead) because if my life glided so smoothly without the sudden dips, I wouldn't have undergone those intense impactful life experiences that changed me the person I am today. So in a way, yes. But I feel like it starts with believing in yourself and then finding that confidence within me. I'm sure on the first, it won't be perfect but I feel like that's expected. That is what it allows me to approach things differently the next time I'm caught in the same situation. Having a close relation with God I found to be equally important because God is beautiful and amazing. He works in mysterious ways. I learned that ‘Timings everything’, (it can apply to my love life or just about anything) God knows what the extent of what I can handle, so I believe it's okay to take some risks and be daring, but most importantly allowing God into my life is the best thing I can do.

I think that's a bit of an arbitrary question. You can most definitely dream and pursue whoever you want to be there's no question there. But I just think that in certain circumstances other things/issues come in to play that to be perfectly honest prevent a person from being who they truly want to be. Like for example, what about a person in Africa who dreams of coming to America to start her own business, but in truth she has to deal with how to get food and water every day and constantly worrying about getting some disease and taking care of her children as well. I mean its not like a green card and plane ticket for her and her whole family is just gonna fall into her lap not to mention the language barrier and the education barrier too!! I mean I feel for these people but if I have to be honest they just don't have the means to be whoever they want to be and its terrible but true!! And it doesn't just happen in 3 world countries either, some kids are just dealt a bad hand when it comes to parents. I mean what do you expect a child to do do when either the mother or the father is completely out of the picture and the other parent is a complete drug addict who can't take care of themselves let alone a child. The only choice the kid has unfortunately is to presuse illegal ventures just to be able to eat at night!! And your trying to tell me that they have the choice to be whoever they want to be? Ha I doubt it. They're lucky to even come out with a GED.

‘We are what we pretend to be, so we must be careful of what we pretend to be’ - Kurt Vonnegut. This essentially means that you can be whatever you want to be. This also works like ‘Fake it till you make it’ type of attitude. But this quote has far deeper than that. It also says that you are more than mere adjectives that you choose yourself to be defined with - shy-bold; introvert-extrovert; calm-angry etc. We put ourselves into choosen definition of traits and work according to it; which can be easily changed into the traits that you would like to have in you. For more additional information and examples on this thought, read my blogpost on similar topic - How To Change Your Mindset - Power Of Thought

No. It’s a foolish statement that has brought many people heart ache. This does not mean that there are a great many things you can do and there are many things you could do if only you made the effort to do them. However that said if you are not gifted at math you will likely never be a physicist. I once watched a comedian who let’s just say was calorically challenged. He made one joke where he said he was a body builder and pulled back his sport jacket so his stomach that was hanging over his paints/belt could be seen, then he said ‘I didn’t say I was a very good one’ everyone laughed because as a joke this is funny. But as a life choice, that is to pursue a goal/profession you are wholly unsuited for is a tragic waste of time, effort, energy, and heart. We all really need to be circumspect about our own limitations and abilities. As inspector Callaghan/aka Dirty Harry played by Clint Eastwood said ‘a man has got to know his limitations’. Doing so does not mean you are giving up rather it means you are in touch with the skills you do and don’t possess and the skills you are likely to be able ton develop and those that are beyond your grasp. For instance as a man of average height (I am 5’8”) and below average athletic skills I accepted long ago I was never going to be neither a jokey or the starting center for an NBA team. I am not a failure because of this acceptance and many other obvious limitations I am rather self aware. I am all for people pursuing difficult goals as doing so adds energy to life. But tilting at wind mills in an effort to do something you clearly do not have the capacity to do is another matter.

Certainly, why not. That I would suggest is to hold a clear picture in mind of what you want to be. Make sure you put yourself in the picture. Also, continue to be flexible as you move along your path and one thing more. Ask the Universe, Higher Power, however you may characterize the Infinite Intelligence, that your entire process be for the highest good of all concerned. As you go along your path, what you want may change (new information, learning). That’s where flexibility is important. Invoking the highest good is like an insurance policy that what comes forward will be the best from that higher perspective. Also, as things manifest along the way, make sure to express your gratitude as you accomplish the steps on the way to your goal. People often forget this because things may not appear exactly as they wanted. Being grateful aligns you with the energies and results you want more of.

I do know that I am created with potential to achieve much bigger things than either I or my parents thought I was capable of. Another thing I then discovered is that I shouldn't let myself be limited by other people's impressions and expectations of myself. I also learned the hard way not to make negative confessions over myself that make me negative and small minded. Negativity and low self-esteem are ghastly. I fight them daily. My parents never believed I was capable of anything and I have a constant battle to cancel that stuff. Honestly!! Maybe I didn't achieve high academic grades, but I have written over 2000 poems and won first prizes for my hand embroidery..and I surprised myself the other day by achieving a 90percent aggregate in the course i did at Bible School. It's not about what others say about me, but what God knows I'm capable of…in HIM I can do all things! (By faith!!!),. EVERY day I'm climbing mountains and it's been amazing to find out how much potential I contain.

Most people would like to just say Yes you can be but there is a difference between natural ability and work effort. For example I do not have the natural ability to compete in a 100m sprint with Usain Bolt. However, I have the work ethic to get into an Investment bank, study and become a doctor or learn farming in Argentina. You can become many things but not necessarily what you want to be!

Yes we can, we need to be strong minded for this to happen then only we can truly be what we are because it is very easy to fake yourself but it is difficult to be what you truly are and I think we should start saying,thinking and also behaving what we are rather than looking at what the society is going to think about us .

I firmly believe you can, but you have to be realistic in your expectations. For example, you can’t be Superman because you do not possess his supernatural powers, but the best singer, fastest runner, best parent, best employee, or anything a normal person can excel at, you can too if only you devote enough time to it. I believe we have it within us to excel as individuals, it’s just that we are our own worst enemies because we doubt ourselves too much.

Depends. Not on luck but solely your efforts. Thousands of footballers yet there is only one Ronaldo, only one Messi. To be whoever you want to be, you must be ready to do whatever it takes to be that person. Efforts efforts efforts! I can't stress enough. However, by efforts I mean CONSISTENT efforts. Irrespective of failure, blasphemy, slow success, you should have faith in yourself and continue. Also,learn about law of attraction. It helps a lot. Best wishes :)

sometimes , not now .. It's a world of compromises. when you stick to your values, life is difficult. but one has to choose what image he or she should have. after I left my job, still struggling to get it, because very few options for me . it's was but the world is like this we have to bring a change or have to adjust.

Hell no but you can be something you never thought possible figure out your god given natural talents pursue something that uses them.. watch how far you go mine are tenacity, endurance, patience, street smart.. and money management figure out yours and go for it

You have the ability to be and yes you can and that depends on exactly what is it you want to be. Now, anything is a broad terminology and has a different perspective. To be honest in this world and how it is now, being anything that you want to be as a limit because that is the way society’s tradition is. It takes away from you more than it gives back to you.

We CAN be whatever we want to be! The secret of success is single-pointedness towards a desired passion. We are here because of unfinished business from a past life - so whatever it is go for it! We are also here because of the Law of Karma; there is destiny attached to this and therefore do not despair when there are ups and downs in our earth travels and travails! There is a time to play and a time to get down to business of becoming what you really want to be! Go for it and even the angels will work with you!
Absolutely. You just have to fully surrender to God.

You certainly can try to be anything you want however be prepared for some disappointment. You can’t paint masterpieces if you can't paint and you can’t be a rock star shredder if you can’t carry a tune…just sayin’ you can’t do what you can’t do.

Let me start my answer with, is anything you want to be really for you? sometime we tend to desire things based on what other people like, in other words, seeking external validations. With that being said one should be very careful on what he really wants, weather he/she got the right tools(abilities) to help in the journey of claiming the desire of self fulfillment and yh miracles do happen, with the right amount of work, persistence and a speck of luck! I would definitely recommend self discovery before starting your journey, and sky’s the limit.

Well, I am a human being. Anything has nothing to do with being human. I know what you mean, but we all are born on certain day and time, with personal DNA and set of permanent preferences, like if you are energetical donor - you can't become energetical vampire, if you are early bird - you can't become the night owl, if you are left handed, you can't change it. Some people are more flexible, some are just stubborn. You can't change your set of mind. Melancholics can't become Sanquinique or Holerick. It isn't up to you as a person. Your soul is making the choices. Best wishes.

Thanks Nathalie for a2a. You can try; it is your prerogative. You can do a SWOT analysis initially and see if you can go ahead with your objective. If the analysis gives you green signal, that is a good omen. Problem comes when people around consider you acceptable or otherwise in that role. YOU WILL HAVE TO MAKE EFFORT AND EXPEND GREAT DEAL OF ENERGY IN MAKING THOSE HAPPY TO GIVE YOU A CLEAN CHIT. Again, it has to be seen that ‘is the effort okay from benefit-cost ratio?’. If it is manageable, then that is again good news. . . . . . . In totality, you must remove the word ‘anything’ from your question and possibly replace it with ‘something’ to make it look more real. Thanks for reading my point of view.

Why not be the best YOU you can be, improving skills and understanding and relationships, and see where that takes you? I can’t be the worlds best singer, because I’ve not got the biology for it. Nor the worlds tallest giraffe.But by improving myself, building on who I am and what I’m interested in, I can probably do more amazing things than I have ever considered. I just have to stop denying who I am and what I’m about and get on with the business of living, growing, learning, teaching, doing. That’s hard enough. But we don’t know what someone with your giftedness, biology, background, etc could be with continual improvement and application. You might be something we have never seen before. Just make it something kind and helpful, please.
>Can I really be anything I want to be? No. You have limits. You have to set goals that are within those limits. This is not easy, since people have a hard time evaluating themselves.

No, only PollyAnna gets to be exactly what she wants. Pursue relentlessly the fields that you find most facinating , and in time you may well land a job that suits both your interests and talents. rand

What I would do is find out the steps I needed to take to become that thing I wanted to become. When you have a big goal, breaking it down makes it easier to handle. If you wanted to write a novel, you would focus on one chapter at a time or one page at a time. Such as becoming a doctor, I would need to go to medical school, complete a residency, get board certified and then find somewhere to practice medicine such as a hospital or private practice. Or if I wanted to start a non profit, I would look up the steps to open a non profit in my state. This would involve evaluating a need that my non profit would serve and how it would go about meeting this need in the community. This might involve filing articles of incorporation and filing for 501(c)(3) status.

i believe yes, but the reason people never attain their goals is that are not prepared to do what’s really necessary to get them, it may be too hard, time consuming and mean sacrifice they dont want to make
Personally, I’d like to become Scarlett Johansson's chair and have her sit on me every day… doubt it’s going to happen any time soon, though.

Make your cookbooks full of philosophy, poetry, religion, psychology, history, literature, art, science, and all there is to learn. Try to learn one thing every day. I recently was just looking back over the past 12,000 days and realizing how much I’ve become what I wanted to be. Hermann Hesse has said that “the most important thing for man to do is to find himself.” Start by reading his great works. He won a Nobel Prize for Literature. Good luck.
You can do anything your heart says you can do and don’t let anybody tell you different. If you truly believe you can do it then you surely can.
Nope. You can’t be a helicopter. You can’t be in the under18 soccer team if you’re over 18. You can’t make into the nba just because you want to. We can make dozens of examples as you can see.
You may not be able to be what you want to be but if you pursue it with heart and passion, you will likely find that you will be satisfied and successful.
No. Try as I might, I will never have a prehensile tail or spotted fur. Make realistic goals for yourself.
Can't be nobody else ,luckily nothing to prove to anyone. NYC is for relic boring !!.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Reginald Cristofer Rogoff

response.answer_text: Don't know. However, it really is worth putting energy into trying. If you try but fail, that is not nearly as bad as never having tried at all.
No. I want to be a frog. I believe that if a princess were to stumble upon me, so to speak, she might kiss me. Not sure what would happen next.
Hi Reginald, thank you for the A2A. I’m a white, straight, western, sane, educated, male. Why would I want to be anyone else, I already hit the ‘prejudice’ jackpot ffs.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Reginald Cristofer Rogoff

response.answer_text: If you put your mind to it and work hard at it. Then the answer is yes
NO. If you dont have a great singing voice to begin with, no amount of practice will make you a singing superstar.
Q: “Can I really be anything I want to be?” Within reason.
